channel.title: An Introduction to Data Science Methods in Education
channel.description: Recent content on An Introduction to Data Science Methods in Education

item.title: About Hugo XMin
item.description: XMin is the first Hugo theme I have designed. The original reason that I wrote it was I needed a minimal example of Hugo themes when I was writing the blogdown book. Basically I wanted a simple theme that supports a navigation menu, a home page, other single pages, lists of pages, blog posts, categories, tags, and RSS. That is all. Nothing fancy. In terms of CSS and JavaScript, I really want to keep them minimal.

item.title: Assignments
item.description: Homework (12-14) Weekly homework. To be submitted in the form of an R Markdown file (.Rmd) via Canvas. There are a few weeks in which we may not have homework for different reasons; why the number of homeworks is listed as 12-14. Individual final project Complete an individually-designed project that can take different forms (R Markdown Report, interactive Shiny app, interactive dashboard, etc.) related to identifying and solving a data-related problem in education using R (due approximately two-thirds of the way through the semester).

item.title: Homework 1
item.description: Loading, setting up Checking that the project is correct First, ensure that this .Rmd file is saved in the directory for the project that you created for the course. First, let’s install and load ggplot2 We’ll do so by running the following line of code. This line of code, though, is a bit different from most: it installs a new R “package” with specific, additional functionality. Installing R packages is very common.

item.title: Homework and Readings
item.description: Week 1 None Week 2 Homework: Homework 1: https://github.com/alishinski/course-website/blob/master/content/homework/HW1.Rmd Readings: Data Science in Education Using R (DSIEUR) chapter #3: https://datascienceineducation.com/c03.html Week 3 Readings: R for Data Science Chapter #12 Tidy Data: https://r4ds.had.co.nz/tidy-data.html

item.title: Presentations
item.description: Week 1: RMD, HTML, PDF Week 2: RMD, HTML, PDF

item.title: Schedule
item.description: Week Date Unit Topic Homework Assignment Exam Week 1 Aug 19 1: Getting started Introductions to each other and to data science HW1 Week 2 Aug 24,26 Foundational skills: Projects, functions, packages, and data HW2 Week 3 Aug 31, Sep 2 2: Exploring data Wrangling and “tidying” data HW3 Week 4 Sep 7, 9 Summarizing data descriptively HW4 Week 5 Sep 14,16 Visualization data with the grammar of graphics HW5 Week 6 Sep 21, 23 More visualization with the grammar of graphics (and some data wrangling) HW6 Week 7 Sep 28, 30 Color, stacking and dodging bars, and faceting HW8 Week 8 Oct 5, 7 Summarizing data in tables HW9 Week 9 Oct 12, 14 More on tables and a gentle introduction to modeling HW10 Week 10 Oct 19, 21 3: Drawing conclusions Estimating parameters HW10 Final project proposal Week 11 Oct 26, 28 Making inferences about effects HW11 Week 12 Nov 2, 4 Communicating results effectively HW12 Week 13 Nov 9, 11 4: Looking ahead A buffet of advanced methods (Part 1) HW13 Week 14 Nov 16, 18 A buffet of advanced methods (Part 2) HW14 Week 15 Nov 23 A buffet of advanced methods (Part 2) HW14 Week 16 Nov 30 A buffet of advanced methods (Part 2) HW14 Finals Week (Due by Dec 5) Final project and presentation, Curating resources

item.title: Syllabus
item.description: An Introduction to Data Science Methods in Education University of Tennessee, Knoxville Course Section: TPTE 695 (PhD) and STEM 599 Meeting Time and Place: Thursday, 2:50 – 4:05 pm (online synchronous) Course Credit Hours: 3 Zoom Meeting: https://tennessee.zoom.us/j/94135227830 Course Website: https://f21-intro-to-data-sci-methods-in-ed.netlify.app/ Faculty Contact Information Dr. Alex Lishinski (they/them) alishins@utk.edu Zoom: https://tennessee.zoom.us/j/2299533064 Website: https://www.alexlishinski.com Please don’t hesitate to email or contact me on Slack with updates, questions or concerns. I will try to respond within 24 hours during the week and 48 hours on the weekend.
